abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as satisfactory
            with project sustainability as likely. Overall, the world
            Bank's performance is rated as satisfactory. Borrower
            performance overall has to be rated satisfactory as, despite
            the volatile political situation, frequent Government
            reshuffles and subsequent changes in personnel, most
            components were executed. Lessons learned included the
            following: Working with several co-financiers introduces
            more complexity in implementation that can hamper the
            implementation of the project beyond the Bank's
            control--the lesson learned is that agreements between the
            government and individual co-financiers should be signed by
            the time the project becomes effective. The Ministry of
            Education had a weak implementation capacity--staff lacked
            qualifications in project management, procurement, financial
            management, and monitoring and evaluation, which resulted in
            delays as well as unnecessary energy and time spent in
            communication and reviewing. Extra care should be paid to
            recruitment and appointment of staff working in the project,
            based only on performance. Co-financiers should pay
            particular attention to technical assistance assignments and
            include the Bank and the client in the selection process.
            Even in the case in which radical changes are foreseen,
            capacity building should start within existing
            structures--if not, existing structures will oppose changes,
            while the newer ones will never succeed to enforce them.
